conclusion: Temperature at state A, \( T_A = -73^\circ C = 200 \, \text{K} \), Internal energy change from A to C, \( \Delta U = 200 \, \text{J} \), Standard conditions: 1 mole of an ideal gas occupies 22.4 L at 1 atm and 273 K, Avogadro's number, \( N_A = 6.0 \times 10^{23} \, \text{mol}^{-1} \)

State A: \( p_A = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}, V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \), State B: \( p_B = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}, V_B = 4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \), State C: \( p_C = 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}, V_C = 4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \)

premise: Using ideal gas law for state A: \( p_A V_A = nRT_A \)
Using ideal gas law for state C: \( p_C V_C = nRT_C \)
Using internal energy change: \( \Delta U = nC_v \Delta T \)
